Description: This presentation will develop concepts on how diet is linked to cellular metabolism and on how metabolism intersects with chromatin and epigenetics.  The substrates used to modify nucleic acids and chromatin are affected by nutrient availability and the activity of metabolic pathways. Thus, cellular metabolism constitutes a component of chromatin status and thereby of genome regulation. I will describe the biochemical and genetic principles of how metabolism can influence chromatin biology and epigenetics, discuss the functional roles of this interplay in developmental and cancer biology, and present future directions in this emerging area.  As a model to study this question, I will talk about methionine metabolism in health and cancer.  Further, methionine content in human food and dietary patterns will also be discussed.
